note.p: The Dokumentationszentrum des Bundes Jüdischer Verfolgter des Naziregimes (BJVN) was founded by Simon Wiesenthal in 1961 in Vienna, which he directed up until his death. The Documentation Centre[TP1] collected a large number of documents on Nazi perpetrators, Nazi crimes and collaborators. The material, comprising some 8,000 files, together with the Documentation Centre's extensive correspondence, is currently housed in the Simon Wiesenthal Archive of the Vienna Wiesenthal Institute for Holocaust Studies (SWA-VWI), with the majority of documents dating from 1945 to 2005.

Polish-Austrian Holocaust survivor, architect, writer. From the day of his liberation from the concentration camp Mauthausen onwards, he made it his life's task to find Nazi war criminals and collaborators and bring them to justice. His creed in this battle was ”Justice, not Revenge”, as one of his many books is called. He was also committed to combating post-war anti-Semitism, as well as commemorating the Holocaust and educating young people.
Lviv born Jewish-American pianist and composer, son of Josef Chajes.
Father of Julius Chajes, Lviv-native Jewish physician at the beginning of 20th century.
Galician-Austrian rabbi, historian and Zionist activist.

body.p: The letter was received by the Jewish Documentation Center on Feb. 21, 1977

In order that humanity can survive, we have to accept and act according to certain moral laws. The most important moral law is that a man is responsible for his deeds. If we free him from this responsibility then the world would end up in chaos.
Every murderer, every thief could plead innocence by blaming circumstances or situations which made him commit his crime.
Therefore, the SS officer who confessed to you is guilty for the crimes which he committed and has to bear the full consequences.

You as a representative of your people (in his eyes) had no right to forgive him. You did show him compassion by listening silently to his confessions thus easing his conscience in the hour of his death. You even went further – by seeking out his mother and by not letting her know that her “good” son, as she believed it behaved like a beast and not like a human being.
You had two “mitzvot” and I admire you for it.
We cannot accept the doctrine that if you are hit on one cheek offer the other cheek. This doctrine would perpetuate eternal slavery.

I was born in Lwów on Dec. 21, 1910 on ul. Jagiellońska 24. My father, Dr. Josef Chajes, was head of the gynecological dept. of the Jewish hospital on Sw. Anny. My father was a second cousin to Dr.Perez Zwi Chajes of Vienna.
